Award.AwardTitle: CDI-Type II: Collaborative Research: Computing Supermassive Black Hole Mergers in Astrophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Super-massive black hole mergers are believed to happen with significant frequency, but direct detection through gravitational wave observations remains only a hope for the future. An alternate path toward finding them lies through photon observations of their effects on nearby gas, but little is known for certain about what sorts of light might be produced. To solve this problem, this project is a systematic theoretical study of the electromagnetic output from these events, from the precursor stage of binary black holes, through the event itself, and including the post-merger relaxation phase. Because the quantity and character of the light radiated depends in a fundamental way on how much mass is brought to a given distance from the black holes, coordination between the initial evolution of the system, when the binary separation is large and Newtonian dynamics applies, and the merger itself, when general relativity controls the system, is an essential part of the plan. By enabling conventional telescopic observation of these systems, the aim is to create an entirely new subfield - the astronomy of black hole mergers.

These science goals can be reached only by the construction of a highly-sophisticated computational system. High-performance computation is essential because tracking the dynamics of these events involves simultaneously solving the equations of radiation transport and magneto-hydrodynamics (MHD) in a general relativistic spacetime, as well as the highly nonlinear Einstein Field Equations. Data communication requirements are also extremely challenging because even defining the dynamical spacetime of a black hole merger can require as much as several petabytes. This effort is therefore strongly multidisciplinary because of the multiple kinds of expertise needed: numerical relativity, MHD simulation, data compression, 3-d visualization, and observational astronomy.

This project will have significant additional impact, ranging from training graduate students and post-doctoral fellows in a brand-new interdisciplinary field (fluid motion in dynamical spacetime) to a variety of public outreach efforts. The junior researchers will need to learn advanced computational techniques, including parallel computing, the use of very large data sets, and scientific visualization. Public education efforts will include conventional presentations, the use of simulation animations in multi-media educational programs, and integration of simulation animations into music and dance. The necessary computational developments, such as the planned aggressive data compression procedure, will be of great value to scientists in other fields exploring ever larger dynamical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit---

In the standard theory of galaxy formation, small galaxies merge to form larger ones, and as they do so, the massive black holes housed in their centers find their way to the center of the new, merged galaxy and become gravitationally bound to each other.   This binary black hole system collects interstellar gas, which orbits around it.  It is expected that interactions with both this orbiting gas and nearby stars cause the orbit of the binary black hole to shrink gradually. Ultimately, when the binary becomes very tight, it radiates so much energy in gravitational waves that the binary tightens even faster, and soon thereafter the black holes merge.   At the merger, an enormous amount of energy is liberated in a burst of gravitational waves lasting as long as a few hours.   Planned space missions may be able to detect these gravitational waves, using technology closely related to that used in the ground-based Laser Interferometric Gravitational Observatory (LIGO) experiment, so successful in seeing black hole mergers of much smaller mass.

It has been the goal of this program to use numerical simulations to predict how much light should be emitted in the course of a supermassive black hole merger. If all goes well, guided by our predictions, astronomers may be able to find such mergers even before these space missions are launched; however, without good quality predictions, the search will be far more difficult.

We have made considerable progress along these lines.  In particular, we have overturned the long-standing view on the part of most of the astronomical community that there should be so little gas close to the merging black holes that they would be extremely dim.  Our numerical simulations have demonstrated that in fact these systems should often be quite bright throughout the run-up to merger.   Moreover, we have also identified two ways in which the character of their light contrasts sharply with the light emitted by single supermassive black holes with large quantities of gas orbiting nearby, objects (called quasars) that are much more common than black hole pairs.

Further problems remain to be solved, principally the extremely complex problem of what happens to gas close to a pair of black holes during the time of the actual black hole merger.   In order to overcome the tremendous technical complexities involved, we have developed an entirely new simulation software infrastructure, called a "multipatch method" that allows different regions to be treated independently of one another, but in a fashion that keeps them closely coordinated.   We expect that in future work with this new software we will be able to pursue the evolution of merging supermassive black holes all the way to its climax.

Broader impacts---

It is possible that the greatest external impact of our work will be the multipatch method.   This method is extremely general in character, applying to numerical simulations of virtually all kinds of fluid motions.   For this reason, we would not be surprised if it finds useful application far beyond the bounds of astrophysics, or even far beyond the bounds of physics.    In an indication of its potential broad use, we are already receiving inquiries from scientists at Department of Energy laboratories, whose only knowledge of our work is conference talks given by members of our team, about possible application of our method to their problems.

In addition, we have also trained a number of young scientists, graduate students and post-docs, in the techniques of very large-scale numerical simulation.   We have also participated in numerous lay-public outreach events.
